Message: My mom was as in an abusive relationship with her boyfriend when I was 12-14.
He would beat her badly,leaving her with broken ribs, black eyes, etc.
My mom would always tell me and my sister to just ignore it.
One day, I came home from a friends house, and my little sister (10 at the time) was crying.
She told me he hit her and threw against the wall, and showed me the bruises.
In that moment, I went dark.
We lived in a poor trailer trash town with high crime,so I had plenty of friends who had guns.
The next day, I went to one of my good friend‚Äôs house and told him everything, and we got in the car and drove to mom‚Äôs bf‚Äôs house and waited for him.
When he got home and got out of his car, my friend handed me the gun,
I got out and walked up to him, said 'fuck you bitch' and shot him.
I was arrested shortly after, and somehow they had no idea who he as with (no witnesses to say the make of the car), so I never gave up my friend, as he didn‚Äôt shoot him.
I was charged with murder and sentenced to juvenile life.
I spent 2 years in a juvenile detention facility and was transferred to a placement facility that was more focused on rehabilitation and structure until I was 21, when I was released.
AMA
How different was juvy from the rehab place?
Was it hard adjusting to the world once u got out?
The juvie was more prison style (though toned down) so it was more strict and confined.
The placement facility was more like an almost boot camp, though not as harsh/militaristic.
It was hard.
I was still 14 at heart, since even though I matured,
I had no idea about the world going on outside, so everything I knew was from age 14
How‚Äôs your mom doing now?
She‚Äôs a lot better.
She‚Äôs married to a really good guy,
so it all worked out
Why does that matter?
New stepdad was like  ‚ÄúYour son is in prison for what now?‚Äù Lol
lol
he and I have actually talked about that.
He was surprised at first, and a little put off.
But he had it explained to by my family and family friends, and he then was on my side
That's cool,
I‚Äôm sorry that that asshole put you in that position.
You had to choose between your freedom or allow your sister and mother to continue living in fear.
As a young kid your opinions are limited
and you did what you had to do
What parts of growing up did you miss while inside,
and what's your plan to build your future w/o them?
The biggest part that I missed was watching my little sister grow up.
and still were very close as her and my mom came to visit me a lot.
But I just can‚Äôt help but feel bad for missing her formative years.
We are still close and hang out a lot, so I guess it‚Äôs a rebuilt.
Do you still have a relationship with your mom?
How is your mental health now after going thru that all?
We‚Äôve had ups and downs.
As I got around 17/18, I started to learn about the world,
which made me really angry at my mom for telling us to ignore it,
putting my sister and I‚Äôs health at risk.
She is very apologetic about it, and we rebuild our relationship,
so no I‚Äôd say it is pretty normal.
I don‚Äôt mean to sound like a cold and unemotional person,
but it didn‚Äôt really mess with my mental health besides being sad that I couldn‚Äôt go home or see my sister.
I‚Äôm not sure, it‚Äôs hard to explain.
I‚Äôm sorry you went thru this..
count it as a blessing that your mental health has been good!
Keeping you in my prayer‚ù§Ô∏è
It is abusive that your mother kept you in that situation
and I don't blame you for what you did.
I'm glad you two have patched things up.
I wish you nothing but the best in the future!
I used to work in dv.
Often ones choices are shitty or shittier.
No good choices there.
I‚Äôm glad you are relatively good.
I wish that our systems were more fictional and helped people.
Self care is the best thing you can do for yourself in working in social services.
You will never repair the world but you can make small changes for individuals.
Also sometimes all you can do is listen and it‚Äôs fucking painful but it is also an incredibly powerful tool.
I wish you the best.
How's your relationship with your sister now?
Is she/has she been ok?
Me and my sister are very close.
They visited me a lot so our relationship never really soured.
She‚Äôs doing very well
now she‚Äôs about to graduate from college.
Thats awesome!
Hope you succeed in whatever ventures you take!
Do you regret shooting him?
In terms of emotionally, no.
He was abusive and cruel.
But I do regret not being able to see my sister grow up,
and I do regret traumatizing his family, as they did lose a family member as well,
but I don‚Äôt feel bad for doing it to him‚Ä¶
I don‚Äôt blame you for what you did.
I‚Äôm glad you are out now.
This is the most genuine and truly empathetic response i could ever imagine.
You're a good person, OP.
You clearly have put the work in and are in the right headspace to help others.
faith restored for a bit
What was the first thing you did as a free man?
Did you see/speak to his family during all the courtroom stuff?
What‚Äôs your favourite colour?
I apologized,
and they obviously didn‚Äôt care to hear it.
But I understand.
Ate food, slept in a regular bed, and hung out with my sister
What was the first thing you ate when you got out?
Pizza from my favorite pizza place
lol
Ooooh
good choice! ü§§
what toppings?
Bacon, sausage, pepperoni
No pineapple!?
You‚Äôre missing out.
I think people who like pineapples on pizza need to be incarcerated.
This is coming from an ex-con
üòÇ
fair enough.
Don‚Äôt knock it till you try it.
i'm guessing these assholes who didn't care to hear it,
also didn't care about the abuse that he dished out that caused his death.
i'm sure they fought to have you given more time like, life in prison.
but i digress
Unfortunately, I've found that abusers' families do not want to see how awful their son/daughter, brother/sister, etc. have been.
It sucks...
but they will believe anything and everything to keep the mindset that their abusive family member was an "angel."
And this entire paragraph is proof for second chances with youth.
You murdered him, you had an excellent reason to do so,
and you still have empathy for those who loved him.
I believe that you would make an excellent trial judge
Do you feel any pride for taking him out?
Not in a 'I love to murder' way but in a 'I'm glad I did what needed to be done' way.
I‚Äôm not proud,
but I do believe that I did the right thing,
and am happy that I got my mom and sister out of the position
how's your sister doing?
are close are you to her?
We are very close.
She‚Äôs doing great
and is close to graduating college.
How are you doing?
I‚Äôm doing better.
I‚Äôm currently in school for social work.
I want to help kids in abusive situations learn to cope and navigate with it all in a healthy manner, unlike my situation
legend
Absolute legend
Bravo!
I bet you will make a beautiful difference in a few lives with your work, and your unfortunate experience.
I don't have an actual question
but I do hope you did not suffer too much while in juvie.
A close friend of mine is a Social Worker
and she loves her job.
I collect household items and clothing for her from my friends and neighbors,to add to my own bags of stuff
I no longer want/need, for her
because there is so little funding that even buying such things at thrift stores can be out of budget for clients out on their own for the first time.
You quite possibly saved your mom's life, if not also your own life and that of your sister.
It's tragic that abusers so often get away with it
repeatedly but hell, you can't even know how many people you saved as he might have gone on to terrorize another family.
Hugs
and best wishes to you.
Thank you!
I believe we should be thanking you.
Putting yourself out there for younger people to help prevent them from making a life changing decision
, THANK YOU!!!!
Great man
From what i've read in your OP and comments....
You stood up for your family and protected them.
My guess is you prevented a lot of pain and suffering.
Do i condone murder.
No.
That having said..
i salute you!
Wish you all the best.
as there were no witnesses how did you get caught
That thought crossed my mind, too.
Wouldn‚Äôt a ballistics report determine what type of gun?

Illegal gun.
Wouldn‚Äôt have traced back to him
‚ÄúWho wanted this guy dead?‚Äù
would probably solve the problem
unless he voluntary gave him self up a case needs to be built up
saying this person is most likely the killer doesn't get you thrown in jail.
As he stated first there was no witnesses
It should be a pretty significant amount of the story that has been glossed over .
There were witnesses.
None of them were able to identify the other person
Because the guy died ‚Ä¶??
And they always look at family relations first
and no doubt this guy gave himself up right OP
there just seems to be a large chunk of the story that is glossed over
the being caught part should have taken over half the story
when guys are in jail I'm sure the bit they process most is they way they got caught and what they did to get detected.
I haven‚Äôt been on this account in a while,
but to answer this, I didn‚Äôt do my crime sneakily.
It was daylight (evening, so dimmed, but still daylight)
and people in his neighborhood knew me because sometimes me and my family would go over there,
but they didn‚Äôt know my friend
and I didn‚Äôt give him up.
The gun wouldn‚Äôt be traced to my friend
because it was an illegal gun
and from what I heard, he got rid of it afterwards and got a new gun.
I was arrested at my moms house.
Hope that clears some stuff up
What an insult to charge you with murder after what this sack of shit had done!
Are you angry with the justice system for punishing you?
Yes and no.
I went to him, so it was premeditated, not an act of active defense,
I get it.
Thought I wish they didn‚Äôt sentence me to juvenile life considering the circumstances
I'm sorry this happened to your family, and his family too.
It seems so unfair that you had to do time for this.
Did your lawyer fight hard to defend you?
Yes, but since I went to my moms bf instead of it being an active defense, it was premeditated,
so I understand from a judicial standpoint
That makes sense.
I hope the rest of your life is fantastic!
Your sacrifice saved your mom and sisters life.
They are happy and doing well because of your actions that day.
Lowkey ur kind of a hero imo
Ehh not really.
The bf sounded like an asshole, but there‚Äôs so many better solutions than committing one of the worst felonies.
There are services to help with those kind of abusive situations, even in those rural areas.
Try instead to get the abusive bf locked up, OP would face no consequences and could testify as a witness to the abuse.
There‚Äôs also the fact the abusive bf‚Äôs family exists.
They didn‚Äôt deserve to suffer a loss, even if the murder victim wasn‚Äôt a great person.
Follow this advice and the bf gets one night in jail and a court date and your family is dead
Not necessarily.
You can get restraining orders and legally separate from the bf.
And with that, OP‚Äôs family would not be in danger.
Plus, you can‚Äôt murder out of speculation that your family would be in danger otherwise.
All that might do best case scenario is reduce the sentence.
I can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm the only one with a brain here not advocating for murder.
Murder is a high-level crime
, and even in cases like this it is absolutely not the right thing to do and causes more damage than good.
OP seems to be more mature and reasonable now,
but I will never condone the murder of people.
Edit: holy shit, you guys are unbelievable.
I‚Äôm being downvoted for not supporting murder.
You guys are scaring me, you‚Äôre all potential murderers.
Oh, how did I forget the restraining orders?
I wish there were laws against assaulting and abusing significant others and children that would prevent the need for a restraining order in the first place.
I forgot, there is.
I don‚Äôt know what fantasy land you live in where you think he would fear trespassing when he clearly hasn‚Äôt cared about the other crimes he‚Äôs committing.
Whatever crimes he‚Äôs committed is still not a justification for OP‚Äôs murder of this bf.
Vigilante justice is illegal and also a really backwards way of thinking.
OP was a child of 14.
What did he know?
Should his mother have gotten them out? Yes.
Should she never have subjected OP and his sister to this? Yes.
Should the boyfriend have never abused any of them? Yes.
Let‚Äôs just say it was a terrible situation and OP did the only thing he knew at the time to protect his sister.
Still doesn‚Äôt excuse murder.
I can‚Äôt believe so many people here are defending murder.
I‚Äôm now concerned about everyone on this thread, because they‚Äôre all outing themselves as homicidal.
Vengeance never wins.
I absolutely agree and I didn't downvote you.
Vengeance gets us nowhere. Ever.
History proves that repeatedly.
But you are thinking in pretty binary terms and without context.
OP was 14 years old with an undeveloped prefrontal cortex and living in a hellish situation.
He murdered.
He absolutely deserved to be made responsible for this with thought and judgment given to the extenuating circumstances, which are often included in the law.
He served time.
He was punished.
And he got help.
